intro: Lipochaeta lavarum var. salicifolia, commonly known as the willow-leaved lipochaeta, is a flowering plant native to Australia. It belongs to the family Goodeniaceae and is characterized by its slender, herbaceous stems and lanceolate leaves that resemble those of willow trees. The plant produces small, tubular flowers that are typically pink or purple, arranged in spikes along the stem. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wetlands or along streambanks. This variety is notable for its ornamental value and ecological importance in supporting local insect populations.
